options.title: No parts
options.description:
Choose **No parts** if you don't currently have the spare parts
and consumables required for the procedure. You can come back
with the parts later, or order them.

options.title: No tools
options.description:
Choose **No tools** if you don't have the required tools or other
equipment (like lifting equipment) needed to finish the repairs.
You can come back later, or ask for support.

options.title: No time
options.description:
Choose **No time** if working hours are over, or if you have
another appointment you must keep, and you will come back for this later.

options.title: No skills
options.description:
Choose **No skills** if you do not have the required training or
certification to complete this procedure, or if you need the
help of others to complete it.

processes.title: Check Steam Heating DO
steps: Enter the "Main" menu by selecting and pressing the "Menu" button
Enter the "Service" menu by selecting and pressing the "Service" button
Enter the "Diagnostics" screen by selecting and pressing the "Diagnostics" button (The "Manual Control" button on versions prior to 1.0)
Select the "Steam Valve" DO on the "Digital Outputs" frame
Press the "OK" button to activate the "Steam Valve" DO
Insert one lead of the multimeter to any socket between the 12. and the 22. sockets on the S11 socket group and insert the other lead of the multimeter to the 7. socket on the S13 socket group

we110/steam/heater-fail/steam-heating-do.title: Steam Heating DO available
processes: we110/steam/heater-fail/Check the Steam Heating DO availability

processes.title: Steam Heating DO available
steps: Enter the "Main" menu by selecting and pressing the "Menu" button
Enter the "Service" menu by selecting and pressing the "Service" button
Enter the "I/O Link" screen by selecting and pressing the "I/O Link" button
Select the Steam Valve DO
Press the "OK" button to enter the edit mode
Change the current DO to one of the available DOs by pressing the up-down direction buttons

we110/steam/heater-fail/steam-heating-do.question: Are there any unused available DOs?

we110/steam/heater-fail/change-steam-hea.title: Change Steam Heating DO
processes: we110/steam/heater-fail/Check the Steam Heating DO availability

processes.title: Change the DO assignment for the Steam Heating
steps: Press the "OK" button to assign the target DO

Press the "Exit" button to exit. At this stage the software will ask you if you want to save the changes. To save your changes select the "Yes" button by pressing the left-right direction buttons and press the "OK" button to confirm the selection
The software will return to the "Service" menu
Detach the S13 socket plug from the back of the Control Panel
Remove the 7. socket terminal from the S13 socket plug by pushing down the fins of the socket terminal with the terminal removal tool
Attach the S13 socket plug into the S13 socket
Raise up the fins of the socket terminal with the terminal removal tool
Detach the S19 socket plug from the back of the Control Panel

Insert the socket terminal into the 6. socket of the S19 socket plug which corresponds to the DO which has been assigned in the DO assignment step in this video (Step no 1). Warning: You have to select the corresponding socket and socket plug if you choose another DO for this procedure. You can find a list of the DOs and their corresponding sockets on the back of the Control Panel
Attach the S19 socket plug into the S19 socket
Enter the "Diagnostic" screen by selecting and pressing the "Diagnostic" button
Select the "Steam Valve" DO on the "Digital Outputs" frame
Press the "OK" button to activate the "Steam Valve" DO

Check the voltage value by inserting one lead of the multimeter into any socket between the 12. and the 22. sockets on the S11 socket group and inserting the other lead of the multimeter into the 6. socket on the S19 socket group

we110/steam/heater-fail/change-steam-hea.question: Does Â±24V DC exist on the DO?

steps: Press the ESB to check if the button can be pressed

we60/emergency-stop-alarm/button-pressed.question: Is the button in the pressed state?

processes.title: Release the ESB
steps: Twist the Emergency Stop Button clockwise â³ to release it
The button should be pushed up by its springs

we60/emergency-stop-alarm/release-esb-ch.title: Check alarm

processes.title: Check the 'Emergency Stop' alarm status
steps: Check the screen for the alert box

we60/emergency-stop-alarm/release-esb-ch.question: Has the alarm message been removed?

we60/emergency-stop-alarm/replace-esb.title: Replace ESB

steps.0: Check the screen for the alert box
steps.00:01.12: Unscrew the two fixing screws on the left edge

processes.title: Replace the ESB
steps: Unscrew the ESB cable terminals from the ESB contact socket
Remove the contact of the ESB from its back by using a screwdriver
Unbolt the plastic nut from the back of the ESB
Pull the ESB from the front of the CP
Put a new ESB into the empty ESB slot
Bolt the plastic nut onto its bolt at the back of the ESB
Plug the contact of the ESB into its socket
Screw the ESB cable terminals into the ESB contact socket

processes.title: Close the left front panel
steps: Close the panel
Fix the latch
Screw back the two fixing screws on the left edge

processes.title: Check the 'Emergency Stop' alarm status
steps: Check the screen for the alert box

we60/emergency-stop-alarm/replace-esb.question: Has the alarm message been removed?

processes.title: Turn the power off
steps: Twist the power switch 90Â° anti-clockwise â¤¿

steps.00:01.12: Unscrew the two fixing screws on the left edge

processes.title: Check the contacts on the ESB
steps:
Check the conductivity of the contact sockets with short-circuit test
by inserting the multimeter leads into the contact sockets or the contact
screws and testing for both positions of the contact switch. The contact
should be in short-circuit when the switch is in open position (unpressed)
and the contrary in closed position (pressed)

we60/emergency-stop-alarm/replace-esb-co.title: Replace ESB contact

steps.0: Check the screen for the alert box
steps.00:01.12: Unscrew the two fixing screws on the left edge

processes.title: Replace the contact on the ESB
steps: Unscrew the ESB cable terminals from the ESB contact socket
Remove the contact of the ESB from its back by using a screwdriver
Plug the new ESB contact into its socket
Screw the ESB cable terminals into the ESB contact socket

processes.title: Check the 'Emergency Stop' alarm status
steps: Check the screen for the alert box

we60/emergency-stop-alarm/replace-esb-co.question: Has the alarm message been removed?
